element.name: Study ID or Number
element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the Observation is aware of its relevance to the Study.

element.name: Study Name
element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the Observation is aware of its relevance to the Study.

element.name: Transmission Type
element.gap: Determine from type of call to service (requesting all data vs incremental data - e.g. filtering by _lastUpdated). NOTE: If data are not persisted between FHIR and LAB, cannot do incremental data processing (due to lack of delta detection).
element.comment: If the data is being 'pushed' in a message, this could also be conveyed in the MessageHeader.event

element.name: Study Transaction Type
element.gap: Determining whether transactions are insert or update is a task for the data consumer. (NOTE: This requires persistent storage to compare current data with data in the incoming file)
element.comment: This would be conveyed using a transaction Bundle - specifically the Bundle.entry.request.method

element.name: Site ID or Number
element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the Observation is aware of its relevance to the Study.

element.name: Site Transaction Type
element.gap: Determining whether transactions are insert or update is a task for the data consumer. (NOTE: This requires persistent storage to compare current data with data in the incoming file)
element.comment: As per study transaction type (not clear why it happens at both levels - what would it mean to 'delete' at the study level and 'update at the site level?)

element.name: Investigator ID or Number
element.comment:
Will need to decide which id to expose or may need to map to one recognized by the sponsor. If you want the PI for the overall study rather than just for the site associated with the Observation, you'll need to traverse the partOf.resolve() from the study-specific ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the Observation is aware of its relevance to the Study.

element.name: Investigator Name
element.comment:
Will need to decide which name to expose if there are multiples. Can also extract the prefix, given and family names if text isn't specified.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the Observation is aware of its relevance to the Study.

element.name: Investigator Transaction Type
element.gap: Determining whether transactions are insert or update is a task for the data consumer. (NOTE: This requires persistent storage to compare current data with data in the incoming file)
element.comment: As per study transaction type (not clear why it happens at both levels - what would it mean to 'delete' at the study level and 'update at the site level?)

element.name: Screen ID or Number
element.comment:
Study subject is found by finding the StudySubject that corresponds to the same Patient and ResearchStudy as the Observation. Use the identifier.type to differentiate subject identifiers.
No standard way to decide which subject identifier to use. Also no standard way to differentiate subject id from screening id from spare subject id.

element.name: Subject ID or Number
element.comment:
Study subject is found by finding the StudySubject that corresponds to the same Patient and ResearchStudy as the Observation. Use the identifier.type to differentiate subject identifiers.
No standard way to decide which subject identifier to use. Also no standard way to differentiate subject id from screening id from spare subject id.

element.name: Spare subject level ID or Number
element.comment:
Study subject is found by finding the StudySubject that corresponds to the same Patient and ResearchStudy as the Observation. Use the identifier.type to differentiate subject identifiers.
No standard way to decide which subject identifier to use. Also no standard way to differentiate subject id from screening id from spare subject id.

element.name: Subject Sex
element.comment:
Consider whether patient personal information is required for sponsor to perform patient reconciliation. If not, do not send this data element. The US-core birth-sex extension (if it is present) may be more consistently populated than Patient.gender.
If patient gender is sent, the values must be mapped from the FHIR vocabulary to the LAB standard: male -> M female -> F other -> U unknown -> U

element.name: Subject Sex Code List ID
element.gap: For FHIR, the administrative gender code list is fixed, so no need to send it in the instance. If there's a need to convey alternate gender codes, then those would appear either as Observation values or as extension values on Patient (the former for clinical information, the latter for administrative purposes). In either event, the code would be in CodeableConcept.coding which allows identifying both the code system and (if relevant), the version

element.name: Subject Race
element.gap: There's an US-core extension (us-core-race) for capturing this in the U.S. and the possibility that other countries will define their own extensions. Note that this is for administrative, not clinical purposes. Genetic heritage would typically be captured as an Observation
element.comment:
Consider whether patient personal information is required for the sponsor to perform patient reconciliation. If not, do not send this data element.
If patient race is sent, use the us-core-race extension in FHIR.

element.name: Subject Race Code List ID
element.gap: Race, whether captured as an extension or observation value is generally a CodeableConcept allowing capturing both code system and (if relevant) version. Race is highly variable from country to country (both whether it's allowed and how it's coded), so there's no standard element for this in the core spec.

element.name: Subject Initials
element.gap:
Consider whether patient personal information is required for the sponsor to perform patient reconciliation. If not, do not send this data element.
If required, be sure to send only the initials, derived from the name.
element.comment: Note that name.text will typically contain the full name, but *can* contain initials only. If the full name is present, initials can be extracted by looking at the given and family name components and converting to initials

element.name: Subject Date Of Birth
element.gap: Consider whether patient personal information is required for the sponsor to perform patient reconciliation. If not, do not send this data element.
element.comment: Note that precision can vary (YYYY, YYYY-MM or YYYY-MM-DD)

element.name: Visit ID or Number
element.comment: No standard way to decide which identifier to use if multiples are present

element.name: Visit Name
element.gap: In practice, visit name would be the ActivityDefinition.title for the activity in the protocol associated with the encounter. There is no standard extension for this link (though one will be defined). Most clinical systems won't actually capture this, so the determination will need to be made at time of data extraction based on the protocol
element.comment: See LB mapping comment

element.name: Visit Type
element.gap: This is essentially whether the visit is tied to a particular activity within the PlanDefinition (study protocol) or not. Given that in non-study-specific systems, there won't typically be a linkage even when the encounter *is* driven by the study, this will generally need to be populated algorithmically on extension
element.comment:
This could theoretically be distinguished by whether there was a link to a CarePlan activity or ActivityDefinition. Alternatively, you could use an extension or tag. (What's 'planned' for one study might be unplanned for another)
This would be Encounter.reasonCode

element.name: Visit Type Modifier
element.comment: This would be Encounter.reasonCode

element.name: Subject Transaction Type
element.gap: Determining whether transactions are insert or update is a task for the data consumer. (NOTE: This requires persistent storage to compare current data with data in the incoming file)
element.comment: As per study transaction type (not clear why it happens at both levels - what would it mean to 'delete' at the study level and 'update at the site level?)

element.name: Last Active Date and Time
element.gap: FHIR allows capture meta.lastUpdated which reflects when the data last changed on the server in question, but would need to look at Provenance to see when data last changed on a particular system. This typically won't be available.

element.name: Visit Transaction Type
element.gap: Determining whether transactions are insert or update is a task for the data consumer. (NOTE: This requires persistent storage to compare current data with data in the incoming file)
element.comment: As per study transaction type (not clear why it happens at both levels - what would it mean to 'delete' at the study level and 'update at the site level?)

element.name: Central Laboratory ID
element.comment: Will need to look at identifier.type or identifier.system to know which identifier to use. In some cases, performer might be PractitionerRole, in which case, will need to map through PractitionerRole.organization. If there are multiple performers that link to multiple organizations, converter will need to look at Organization.type or have other rules to decide amongst the candidates.

element.name: Central Laboratory Name
element.comment: If there are multiple performers that link to multiple organizations, converter will need to look at Organization.type or have other rules to decide amongst the candidates.

element.name: Specimen ID or Number
element.comment: If there are multiple identifiers, need to look at identifier.system or identifier.type to determine

element.name: Actual Collection Date and Time
element.comment: Most of the time there'll only be a single dateTime. If collected over a period of time (e.g. urine), use the end.

element.name: Planned Collection Time Elapsed
element.comment: Will need to convert value + units into an ISO duration

element.name: Planned Collection Time Elapsed Description
element.comment: The event would be in extension('target').valueReference.display and the time would be in extension('offset').valueDuration value and unit.

element.name: Specimen Condition
element.comment: Will need to choose which coding to extract the code for

element.name: Investigator - Specimen Comment Source
element.comment: Note that practitioners can have multiple identifiers - use type or system to decide which identifier to expose

element.name: Lab - Specimen Comment Source
element.comment: Note that organizations can have multiple identifiers - use type or system to decide which identifier to expose

element.name: Specimen Material ID
element.comment: If multiple codes are present, filter based on system

element.name: Specimen Material Name
element.comment: If multiple codes are present, filter based on system. Translation may be required

element.name: Specimen Material Code List ID
element.comment: If multiple codings are present, will need to decide which to use

element.name: Subject Age at Collection
element.gap:
If captured as an Observation, this would be in the ValueQuantity.code derived from the patient.birthDate(Observation.subject (ref:Patient.birthDate).
If the full birthdate cannot be shared, due to country restrictions, use the birth year to derive age information. Due to lost accuracy in having only the year of birth, 'years' would be the default unit. As an alternative use the cqf-relativeTime extension on Patient.birthDate and convey as a relative time to study enrollment

element.name: Subject Age Units
element.gap:
If captured as an Observation, this would be in the ValueQuantity.code derived from the patient.birthDate(Observation.subject (ref:Patient.birthDate).
If the full birthdate cannot be shared, due to country restrictions, use the birth year to derive age information. Due to lost accuracy in having only the year of birth, 'years' would be the default unit.

element.name: Fasting Status
element.comment:
FHIR to CDISC mapping as follows: F -> Y; NF -> N; FNA -> N/A; NG -> Not Applicable (blank)
If fastingStatusDuration is present and non-zero, that would also map to 'Y'. There are times where this can be inferred from the Observation.code.

element.name: Battery Transaction Type
element.gap: Determining whether transactions are insert or update is a task for the data consumer. (NOTE: This requires persistent storage to compare current data with data in the incoming file)
element.comment: As per study transaction type (not clear why it happens at both levels - what would it mean to 'delete' at the study level and 'update at the site level?)

element.name: Test Status
element.comment:
Multiple fields are required to populate this value per the standard.
Use ServiceRequest.status and ServiceRequest.doNotPerform (doNotPerform will only be true if the test is not to be performed) to represent the test status. From these two fields, sponsors will need to translate to the CDISC test statuses: D - Done N - Not Performed X - Cancelled.

element.name: Test Type
element.gap: The normal transmission of data, via FHIR, is for study tests. If non-study test results are required (e.g., AdverseEvent follow-up), these would be obtained via a special request from the data provider. Alternatively, if the system requires this field to be populated, derive whether the test was for the study or not, use the ServiceRequest resource.
element.comment: Differentiation would be whether the Observation was basedOn a particular activity in the CarePlan (scheduled) or tied to a particular ActivityDefinition (Study test)

element.name: Performing Laboratory ID
element.comment: Use "Organization/type" to pick the type of Organization that represents "Performing Lab"

element.name: Lab Test ID
element.comment: Since this is a codeable concept, there may be multiple codes for a test. The sponsor will have to determine which is the "lab's" code vs. "receiver's" code vs. others.

element.name: Additional Test Description
element.comment: Not all notes will necessarily be appropriate to map here. Would need to decide whether to also bring across authors and dates and would need to combined multiple repetitions into a single string.

element.name: Receiver Test ID
element.comment: Observation/code/coding/system/@value ("system" element used to designate the type of code that is being represented (in this case the "ReceiverTest") by the "code" element)

element.name: LOINC Code List ID
element.comment: This will always be 'LOINC'

element.name: Test Level Comments
element.comment: Will need to determine whether to also incude date and author.

element.name: Reported Result Status
element.comment: This has two possible values: P for Preliminary and F for Final.

element.name: Alert Flag
element.comment:
The alert flag generated by the reference ranges applied and tied to the reported result. There are 9 alert flag values:
LP - Low Panic LT - Low Telephone LN - Low Normal N - Normal HN - High Normal HT - High Telephone HP - High Panic AB - Abnormal and blank when not used. It may be necessary to translate from other interpretation codings.

element.name: Delta Flag
element.comment:
The delta flag generated by the reference ranges applied and tied to the reported result. There are three delta flags:
D+ for an increase in value D- for a decrease in value and blank for no flag. It may be necessary to translate from other interpretation codings.

element.name: Exclusion Flag
element.comment:
The exclusion flag generated by the reference ranges applied and tied to the reported result. There are four exclusion flag values:
LX - Low Exclusion HX - High Exclusion EX - Excluded (for exclusions not falling under high or low) and blank for no flag. It may be necessary to translate from other

element.name: Blinding Flag
element.comment: A new code would likely be needed to specifically designate 'blinded'.

element.name: Test Transaction Type
element.gap: Determining whether transactions are insert or update is a task for the data consumer. (NOTE: This requires persistent storage to compare current data with data in the incoming file)
element.comment: As per study transaction type (not clear why it happens at both levels - what would it mean to 'delete' at the study level and 'update at the site level?)

element.name: Toxicity Grade
element.comment: If there are multiple possible systems, the sponsor will have to determine which interpretation corresponds to toxicity grade

element.name: Toxicity Grade Code List ID
element.gap: May need to translate the URI to a CDISC Code List id

element.name: Reported Result Type (C=coded; N=numeric; T=text; R=range; G = GT; L = LT)
element.gap: Determine from the field in which the result resides. valueCodeableConcept vs. valueQuantity vs. valueString Greater than and less than can be determined by valueQuantity.qualifier

element.name: Text Result Code List ID
element.comment: May need to convert from URI to CDISC-recognized 'ID'

element.name: Conventional Numeric Result
element.comment: If the reported result isn't in conventional units, can use the PQ-translation extension to convey a translation.

element.name: SI Numeric Result
element.comment: If the reported result isn't in SI units, can use the PQ-translation extension to convey a translation.

element.name: Conventional Numeric Result Precision
element.comment:
Determine the precision from the value.
Precision is implicitly determined from the attribute Observation/valueQuantity/value/@value If the reported result isn't in conventional units, can use the PQ-translation extension to convey a translation.

element.name: Reported Numeric Result Precision
element.comment:
Determine the precision from the value.
Precision is implicitly determined from the attribute Observation/valueQuantity/value/@value

element.name: SI Numeric Result Precision
element.comment:
Determine the precision from the value.
Precision is implicitly determined from the attribute Observation/valueQuantity/value/@value If the reported result isn't in SI units, can use the PQ-translation extension to convey a translation.

element.name: Conventional Reference Range Low
element.comment: Will need to combine value and unit into a string. If the reported units aren't 'conventional, can use the PQ-translation extension on Quantity to convey a translation.

element.name: Reported Reference Range Low
element.comment: Will need to combine value and unit into a string.

element.name: SI Reference Range Low
element.comment: Will need to combine value and unit into a string. If the reported units aren't SI, can use the PQ-translation extension on Quantity to convey a translation.

element.name: Conventional Reference Range High
element.comment: Will need to combine value and unit into a string. If the reported units aren't 'conventional, can use the PQ-translation extension on Quantity to convey a translation.

element.name: Reported Reference Range High
element.comment: Will need to combine value and unit into a string.

element.name: SI Reference Range High
element.comment: Will need to combine value and unit into a string. If the reported units aren't SI, can use the PQ-translation extension on Quantity to convey a translation.

element.name: Conventional Units
element.comment: If the reported units are not the same as conventional, can convey with the translation extension. Translation to CDISC terminology may be required.

element.name: Reported Units
element.comment: This may require translation to CDISC terminology

element.name: SI Units
element.comment: If the reported units are not SI units, can convey with the translation extension. Translation to CDISC terminology may be required.

element.name: Record Extension Type
element.gap:
Populate with a default value, depending on the type of data being transmitted.
E.g., "BASE"

element.name: Result Class
element.gap: In FHIR, the value will always be 'reported', with the ability to convey translations in an extension. Nothing will differentiate whether a translation is considered 'conventional' or not, so if there are multiple translations present and the receiver can't figure it out by looking, an additional extension may be necessary to differentiate. This can sometimes also be inferred from the Observation.code.

element.name: Model Version
element.gap: Populate with a default value.
element.comment: The version of FHIR in use is conveyed using Resource.meta.profile

element.name: File Creation Date and Time
element.gap: Pull from the message wrapper. (file creation date)
element.comment: Bundle.timestamp

element.name: Transaction Type
element.gap: No mitigation. If required, fill with a default value.
element.comment: As per study.transaction

element.name: Transmission Source ID
element.gap: Pull from the message wrapper.
element.comment: MessageHeader.source.endpoint if using messaging, otherwise determined out of band based on sender authentication process

element.name: Transmission Source Name
element.gap: Pull from the message wrapper.
element.comment: MessageHeader.source.name if using messaging, otherwise determined out of band based on sender authentication process

element.name: Study Identifier
element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the Observation is aware of its relevance to the Study. ResearchStudy links to Patient. Observation links to Patient. If the patients are the same, that establishes the linkage. There's also an extension that allows direct linkage to a 'study' from any resource - if the source system has actually established such a linkage.

element.name: Study Site Identifier
element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the Observation is aware of its relevance to the Study. ResearchStudy links to Patient. Observation links to Patient. If the patients are the same, that establishes the linkage. There's also an extension that allows direct linkage to a 'study' from any resource - if the source system has actually established such a linkage.

element.name: Investigator Identifier
element.comment:
Will need to decide which id to expose. If you want the PI for the overall study rather than just for the site associated with the Observation, you'll need to traverse the partOf.resolve() from the study-specific ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the Observation is aware of its relevance to the Study.

element.name: Subject Identifier for the Study
element.comment:
Study subject is found by finding the StudySubject that corresponds to the same Patient and ResearchStudy as the Observation.
No standard way to decide which subject identifier to use

element.name: Visit Number
element.comment: This won't necessarily correlate with the protocol-defined visit number. Correspondance to a protocol-defined visit will typically require rules-based analysis based on time, encounter type and other factors.

element.name: Visit Name
element.comment:
In most cases, real world data won't have a direct association to a study protocol activity and the link would need to be inferred. However, if it exists, it would map as follows:
We could go through Encounter.basedOn-> ServiceRequest.instantiatesCanonical, you arrive at ActivityDefinition. Encounter should have a standard instantiatesCanonical extension that would allow pointing to the ActivityDefinition. This would be the ActivityDefinition.name. Submit a change request to add the extension

element.name: Lab Specimen ID
element.comment: As reported from the Site

element.name: Date/Time of Specimen Collection
element.comment: NOTE: no mapping included for CDASH LBDAT and LBTIM To map directly, the data must be formatted in ISO 8601 date/time format (e.g., 2015-02-07T13:28:17-05:00)

element.name: End Date/Time of Specimen Collection
element.comment:
NOTE: No mapping included for CDASH LBENDAT and LBENTIM)
To map directly, the data must be formatted in ISO 8601 date/time format (e.g., 2015-02-07T13:28:17-05:00)

element.name: Specimen Collection Duration (for Clinical Research with extended time of collection)
element.comment: Will need to convert value and unit to ISO syntax. E.g. 90 min would convert to PT1H30M

element.name: Specimen Planned Time Point Name (Planned Collection Time Point - time within Encounter)
element.comment: Typically named timepoints won't exist in real-world data and the timing point name will need to be assigned by the sponsor. However, this shows where the data would be expressed in FHIR if it was present there.

element.name: Specimen Planned Elapsed Time from Time Point Reference
element.comment: Typically named timepoints won't exist in real-world data and the timing point offset will need to be calculated by the sponsor. However, this shows where the data would be expressed in FHIR if it was present there. If present, would need to translate to ISO-8601

element.name: Specimen Condition
element.comment:
Recommend submitting change proposals to extend the FHIR vocabulary to include CDISC values. Sponsor will need to decide how to map when FHIR terminology contains codes not present in CDISC.
NOTE: requires an extension to the FHIR vocabulary to include CDISC values (e.g., Refrigerated). An "as collected" version of the SDTM variable is recommended to allow the sponsor to make adjustments to ensure terminology compliance while mapping to SDTM.

element.name: Specimen Type
element.comment:
NOTE: In some cases, this may be inferred from the LOINC.
FHIR terminology is not standardized. Sponsor will need to map to CDISC terminology if raw data does not use CDISC codes. An "as collected" version of the SDTM variable is recommended to allow the sponsor to make adjustments to ensure terminology compliance while mapping to SDTM.

element.name: Fasting Status
element.comment:
FHIR to CDISC mapping as follows: F -> Y; NF -> N; FNA -> N/A; NG -> Not Applicable.
If fastingStatusDuration is present and non-zero, that would also map to 'Y'. In some cases, this may be inferred from the LOINC term (Challenge). For example, Challenge=post CFst to signify a calorie fast.

element.name: Lab Test Condition Met
element.gap: This is an 'ask on entry' question. May be able to determine some conditions, such as fasting, by using other specimen.collection attributes (e.g., fasting status). Others might be captured as components or extensions. Alternatively, obtain this information from the case report form entries.
element.comment: There are explicit elements for Specimen.collection.fastingStatus and collection.fastingDuration. May need extensions for other pre-conditions

element.name: Specimen Collection Position
element.comment: As reported from the lab. Will need to map to CDISC controlled terminology

element.name: Specimen Usability for the Test
element.comment:
Need to translate to blank or N if not received as blank or N
May not be applicable for safety labs.

element.name: Category
element.comment: NOTE: In some cases, this may be inferred from the LOINC. It might also be found by looking for the 'panel' Obsesrvation this Observation is a part of. In most cases, translation will be required to sponsor-defined codes. It may work best for the sponsor to categorize based on TESTCD values and ignore lab-reported and EHR-determined categories entirely.

element.name: Test Status
element.comment:
Sponsor may choose to map a situation in which the entire panel is cancelled as one summary record compliant with SDTM IG examples. Some sponsor may decline to accept cancelled records under specific circumstances (e.g., unscheduled) Sponsor may also choose to populate LBREASND as CANCELLED
Needs to be translated from FHIR vocabulary to SDTM controlled terminology: FHIR -> CDISC: Not performed = NOT DONE Cancelled = NOT DONE Completed = <blank>

element.name: Reason Test Not Done
element.comment: see notes on LBSTAT

element.name: Lab Test or Examination Short Name
element.comment: Translate to compliant terminology (if needed)

element.name: Lab Test or Examination Name
element.comment: Translate to compliant terminology (if needed)

element.name: Reference Range Indicator
element.comment: Must map to CDISC controlled terminology

element.name: Standard Toxicity Grade
element.comment: Must map to sponsor-determind terminology

element.name: Toxicity Grade Code List Version
element.comment: Typically FHIR systems will only populate Coding.version where the terminology is ill-behaved and code meanings change over time. The code system version doesn't convey what value set the user was choosing from (which could be a subset of the codes from the code system or could draw from multiple code systems).

element.name: Toxicity Grade Code List
element.comment: Note that the system doesn't define the value set nor does it specify value set version or code system version(s)

element.name: Lab Ref Range Lower Limit in Orig Unit
element.comment: As reported from the lab.

element.name: Lab Ref Range Upper Limit in Orig Unit
element.comment: As reported from the lab.

element.name: Reference Range (for string value)
element.comment: Sponsor would normalize this.

element.name: Lab Result or Finding in Original Units
element.comment:
Might also include valueQuantity.comparator
CDISC (and sponsors) may have different definitions about what constitutes an "original result". Sponsors will need to make a determination of whether the value found in the Observation.value meets those criteria and is appropriate to be mapped. (In some cases, what's in Observation.value could have been transformed from what was captured at the point of measurement.)

element.name: Reported Units
element.comment: Needs to be translated to match the controlled terminology, if not already compliant

element.name: Lab Clinical Significance
element.comment: As determined by the lab, not the sponsor

element.name: Method
element.comment: Method can cover collection and many other features. In some cases, collection method may be inferred from the Observation.code. Would need to map to CDISC controlled terminology

element.name: Anatomical Region
element.comment: In some cases, the anatomical location can be inferred from the Observation.code. Would need to map to CDISC controlled terminology.

element.name: Run ID
element.gap: Would need to introduce an extension
element.comment: May not be applicable for safety labs.

element.name: Unique Subject Identifier
element.comment:
To find an identifier that was consistent for the subject across studies would typically mean looking to the Patient identifier. However, this may not be appropriate to be exposed directly, so some degree of mapping, obfuscation or anonymization may be required.
In theory, a sponsor specific study-independent identifier could be maintained on Patient alongside other patient identifiers, but this would be unusual in most clinical systems.

element.name: Result Categorization
element.comment: This wouldn't come from the lab. It *could* be added after the fact. If so, this would be the mapping

element.name: Anatomical Region
element.comment: Not differentiated from LBLOC. Not for basic safety labs

element.name: Unscheduled Flag
element.gap:
This can sort of be inferred from the absence of a link to a PlanDefinition or ActivityDefinition, however there are lots of other reasons these links could be missing, so that's not totally reliable. Could look at using an extension or a tag
Not generally used for human clinical trials

element.name: Planned Time Point Number
element.gap: Pull this information from the Clinical Plan (PlanDefinition)
element.comment: Link to the clinical plan would be through the Observation.basedOn link to CarePlan or the instantiatesCanonical link to PlanDefinition or ActivityDefinition

element.name: Analytical Method
element.gap: This does not apply to safety labs.
element.comment: The corresponding values need to be evaluated and aligned accordingly to the CDISC context of --METHOD. Potentially could appear in Observation.method. An extension is required to distinguish.

element.name: Baseline Flag
element.gap: Variable may be deprecated. This information would come from the Sponsor.
element.comment: Could appear in Observation.reasonCode. In practice the notion of 'baseline' is more of a relationship. Any arbitrary Observation might be selected as the 'baseline' for a particular step in the study. As such, the real linkage is the tie to the CarePlan activity that's tied to the ActivityDefinition with a reason of 'baseline'.

element.name: Derived Flag
element.gap: This information would come from the Sponsor.
element.comment: FHIR doesn't use a flag. If an Observation is derived, it should point to the Observations it's derived from with the derivedFrom association. (If that relationship is present, then the Derived Flag is true)

element.name: Study Identifier
element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the Observation is aware of its relevance to the Study. ResearchStudy links to Patient. Observation links to Patient. If the patients are the same, that establishes the linkage. There's also an extension that allows direct linkage to a 'study' from any resource - if the source system has actually established such a linkage.

element.name: Study Site Identifier

cdisc.label: DM.SITEID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the Observation is aware of its relevance to the Study.

element.name: Subject Identifier for the Study

cdisc.label: DM.SUBJID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
Study subject is found by finding the StudySubject that corresponds to the same Patient and ResearchStudy as the Observation.
No standard way to decide which subject identifier to use

element.name: Visit Name

cdisc.label: VISIT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: Encounter should have a standard instantiatesCanonical extension that would allow pointing to the ActivityDefinition. This would be the ActivityDefinition.name. Submit a change request to add the extension

element.name: Visit Date

cdisc.description: The field is not an SDTM variable. The date of a measurement, test observation can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTM components

element.comment: Linked via Observation.encounter

cdisc.label: VSSTAT
cdisc.description: This field is not an SDTM variable. May be used to derive a value into the SDTM variable VSSTAT. If VSPERF="N", the value of VSSSTAT will be "NOT DONE". If VSPErF="Y", VSSTAT should be NULL

cdisc.label: VSDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable VSDTC in ISO 8601 format.

cdisc.label: VSDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable VSDTC in ISO 8601 format.

element.name: Category for Vital Signs

cdisc.label: VSCAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
FHIR allows multiple categorizations at various levels of granularity.
Observation.category.coding.system="http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/observation-category" + Observation.category.coding.code="vital-signs". This combination can be used to extract vital sign data points from EHR system and correctly assign them to the VS domain.

element.name: Subcategory for Vital Signs

cdisc.label: VSSCAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
FHIR allows multiple categorizations at various levels of granularity.
Observation.category.coding.system="http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/observation-category" + Observation.category.coding.code="vital-signs". This combination can be used to extract vital sign data points from EHR system and correctly assign them to the VS domain.

element.name: Vital Signs Group ID

cdisc.label: VSGRPID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: This would typically be done by having the related Observations being 'membersOf' a common parent Observation.

element.name: Vital Signs Planned Time Point Name

cdisc.label: VSTPT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: TimePoints will be represented in FHIR as PlanDefinition.activities. Referencing a PlanDefinition is supported in R5. Can use a standard extension to pre-adopt.

element.name: Vital Signs Completion Status

cdisc.label: VSSTAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: In some instances, VSSTAT="NOT DONE" records will come from FHIR Observation resources where Observation.status="cancelled".

element.name: VS Result or Finding in Original Units

cdisc.label: VSORRES
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: Ensure the value provided from the EHR is considered an actual value (result), an interpretation or range.

cdisc.label: VSORRESU
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.name: Vital Signs Clinical Significance
element.comment: If clinical significance is a boolean, then the mapping is different from the existing http://hl7.org/fhir/ValueSet/observation-interpretation ValueSet. Meaning, the values of "normal", "high", :low", etc. can reside in the --NRIND variable. There are also cases where clinical significant outcome details can exist with corresponding details that don't fit into either of those mentioned buckets.

element.name: Vital Signs Position of Subject

cdisc.label: VSPOS
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: This is often pre-coordinated into the Observation.code, but can also be expressed in the method

element.name: Location of Vital Signs Measurement

cdisc.label: VSLOC
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: Requires knowledge or review of data to ensure location, laterality and directionality are included in the code and can be parsed.

element.name: Vital Signs Laterality

cdisc.label: VSLAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: Requires knowledge or review of data to ensure location, laterality and directionality are included in the code and can be parsed.

element.name: Vital Signs Directionality

cdisc.label: VSDIR*
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: Requires knowledge or review of data to ensure location, laterality and directionality are included in the code and can be parsed.

element.name: Vital Signs Test code

cdisc.label: VSTESTCD
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s). The SDTMIG variable VSTESTCD may be determined from the value collected in VSTESTCD and VSTEST. Both VSTESTCD and VSTEST are required in the SDTM submission datasets. Use appropriate CDISC Controlled Terminology for the test and test code.

element.comment: coding.display and coding.code (plus coding.system)

element.name: Vital Signs Test Name

cdisc.label: VSTEST
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s). The SDTMIG variable VSTESTCD may be determined from the value collected in VSTESTCD and VSTEST. Both VSTESTCD and VSTEST are required in the SDTM submission datasets. Use appropriate CDISC Controlled Terminology for the test and test code.

element.comment: coding.display and coding.code (plus coding.system)

element.name: Vital Signs Sponsor-Defined Identifier

cdisc.label: VSSPID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s). May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.

element.comment: The assigner of the identifier can be explicit or inferred by the Identifier.system. Example: "assigner=sponsor", the value of assigner can either be a simple name using "display" (e.g. "assigner.display=MyPharma" or a reference to an "Organization"

element.name: Vital Signs Repetition Number

cdisc.label: SUPPVS.QVAL
cdisc.description:
The repetition number of test/measurement within the time point ma be preprinted on the CRF (e.g.. multiple measurements of blood pressure, multiple analyses of a sample).
This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPVS dataset as the value of SUPPPVS.QVAL where SUPPVS.QNAM="VSREPNUM" and SUPVS.QLABEL="Repetition Number within time point:. Refer to current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variables in SDTM domains.

element.gap: This could be captured as a specific ActivityDefinition where you'd have a distinct ActivityDefinition for each occurrence. However, it is more likely to be a single ActivityDefinition for the test and an extension would be added on Observation.instantiates to indicate which occurrence is the Observation.

element.name: Study Identifier

cdisc.label: STUDYID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s). I the column with the heading SDTMIG Target.

element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The direct path using AdverseEvent.study will only exist if the system maintaining the AdverseEvent is aware of its relevance to the Study. ResearchStudy links to Patient. Observation links to Patient. If the patients are the same, that establishes the linkage. There's also an extension that allows direct linkage to a 'study' from any resource - if the source system has actually established such a linkage.

element.name: Study Site Identifier

cdisc.label: DM.SITEID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The direct path using AdverseEvent.study will only exist if the system maintaining the AdverseEvent is aware of its relevance to the Study.

element.name: Subject Identifier for the Study

cdisc.label: DM.SUBJID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: Research subject points to patient, adverse event points to patient. Adverse event points to study. Check to see if they are the same in order to establish linkage. When extracting real world evidence either the extraction will be performed in a fully identified mode and de-identification will happen as a subsequent process or the de-identification will already have occurred. Any identify info in the resources will already have real world identification randomized or otherwise made nonsensitive. The mapping is referring to subject.reference not to the identifier element on the clinical resources.

element.name: Any Adverse Event

cdisc.description: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM aCRF is annotated to indicate that the field is NOT SUBMITTED.

element.gap: In FHIR, this would be determined by searching for AdverseEvents with a given subject (possibly also filtered by research study) and excluding those that were entered in error. If a flag were necessary, it would be an extension on Study, not sent on AdverseEvent. It might also be necessary to search for Condition instances, Observation instances, Encounters with particular reasons and other resources if the desire is to have the full set of potential adverse reactions.

element.name: Category for Adverse Event

cdisc.label: AECAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s). I the column with the heading SDTMIG Target.

element.comment:
This is typically sponsor-specific and we would not expect this to come from the site.
In FHIR, an AdverseEvent can be categorized in as many ways as desired with whatever granularity is desired. When converting from FHIR to CDASH, systems will need to look at the FHIR categories (and potentially other information) to determine how best to populate AECAT and AESCAT based on the study-designed categories (unless they've pre-arranged with the EHR to ensure it captures the same codes)

element.name: Subcategory for Adverse Event

cdisc.label: AESCAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
This is typically sponsor-specific and we would not expect this to come from the site.
In FHIR, an AdverseEvent can be categorized in as many ways as desired with whatever granularity is desired. When converting from FHIR to CDASH, systems will need to look at the FHIR categories (and potentially other information) to determine how best to populate AECAT and AESCAT based on the study-designed categories (unless they've pre-arranged with the EHR to ensure it captures the same codes)

element.name: AE Sponsor-Defined Identifier

cdisc.label: AESPID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s). May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.

element.comment: The assigner of the identifier can be explicit or inferred by the Identifier.system.

element.name: Reported Term for the Adverse Event

cdisc.label: AETERM
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.name: Adverse Event Occurrence

cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. Because the SDTM AE domain is intended to hold only AdverseEvents that actually happen, all values collected in AEOCCUR for prespecified AEs should be submitted in a Findings About AdverseEvents data set (FAAE) where FAORRES=the value of AEOCCUR where FATESTCD="OCCUR" in addition, where AEOCCUR=Y, there should be a corresponding record in the AE domain.

element.gap: FHIR only captures AdverseEvents that have actually occurred. A flag about whether a particular potential adverse reaction has been detected or not could be captured using Questionnaire Response

element.name: Prespecified Adverse Event

cdisc.label: AEPRESP
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: If captured within an EHR, this would be an extension on the existing extension that references the ResearchStudy. (An AdverseEvent might be pre-specified for one study and not for another.)

element.name: Ongoing Adverse Event
element.gap: Note that the assertion of 'ongoing' is made at the time the adverse event is recorded, which may or may not be what's needed for submission purposes.

element.name: Adverse Event End Date
element.comment: Need to use a standard extension to pre-adopt the type allowed in R5. Element contains both date and time (if specified).

element.name: End Time of Adverse Event
element.comment: Need to use a standard extension to pre-adopt the type allowed in R5. Element contains both date and time (if specified).

cdisc.label: AESOD

element.comment: Product Relatedness implies that the product is involved in the AE, but it doesn't indicate overdose. After looking through other fields, it does not look like there is a field that would cover this situation. In studies, OD would be a reason why the AE was marked as an SAE.

cdisc.label: AEREL
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

path.value: AdverseEvent.suspectEntity.causality.productRelatedness|AdverseEvent.suspectEntity.causality.assessment with binding to AdverseEventCausalityAssessment value set

Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variables in SDTM domains.

element.comment: Pre-adopting R5 capability via a standard extension. Note that the extension captures all actions taken, so filtration would be needed to select only those related to devices

element.name: Study Identifier

cdisc.label: STUDYID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the AdverseEvent/Condition/AllergyIntolerance/Observation is aware of its relevance to the Study.

element.name: Study Site Identifier

cdisc.label: DM.SITEID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the AdverseEvent/Condition/AllergyIntolerance/Observation is aware of its relevance to the Study. ResearchStudy links to Patient. Observation links to Patient. If the patients are the same, that establishes the linkage. There's also an extension that allows direct linkage to a 'study' from any resource - if the source system has actually established such a linkage.

No standard way to decide which subject identifier to use

element.name: Any Medical History Event

cdisc.description: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM Annotated CRF is annotated to indicate that this field is NOT SUBMITTED

element.gap: If captured, this would be a Questionnaire question. FHIR almost always has some type of history information. Will require review to determine if the history is relevant.

element.name: Category for Medical History

cdisc.label: MHCAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
The sponsors does not typically require this information from the sites.
If needed there are several options to categorize this based on whether something is a Condition/AllergyIntolerance/Observation/etc. This could also include sub-categorize by diagnosis vs. problem, Allergy vs. intolerance or use Observation.category. But in general, the mapping to both CAT and SCAT is going to be driven by what types of categories the study requires or needs.

element.name: Subcategory for Medical History

cdisc.label: MHSCAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
The sponsors does not typically require this information from the sites.
If needed there are several options to categorize this based on whether something is a Condition/AllergyIntolerance/Observation/etc. This could also include sub-categorize by diagnosis vs. problem, Allergy vs. intolerance or use Observation.category. But in general, the mapping to both CAT and SCAT is going to be driven by what types of categories the study requires or needs.

cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MHDTC in ISO 8601 format

element.name: MH Sponsor-Defined Identifier

cdisc.label: MHSPID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s). May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.

element.comment: If FHIR IDs are used for RELREC, then the sponsor should evaluate its use case as necessary prior to mapping.

cdisc.label: SUPPMH.QVAL
cdisc.description: This will generally be set to SYMPTOM ONSET for all resources, as both the onsetDateTime and effectiveDateTime are expected to represent when the symptoms first appeared, not when the diagnosis occurred. However, there are no strict rules in FHIR about when a condition flare-up is considered to be a continuation of a prior condition and when it's a new condition. Thus in some cases, new condition instances could spawn from net new episodes or relapes. Spronsors may need to check for prior condition instances and based on their rules, adjust the value for this field to be EPISODE or something else in some cases.

element.name: Reported Term for the Medical History

cdisc.label: MHTERM
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.name: Medical History Occurrence

cdisc.label: MHOCCUR
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: In general in FHIR, records of the absence of Conditions are not normally captured. If the information revolves around "has the patient had X", that would be accomplished through a Questionnaire.Response

element.name: Medical History Event prespecified

cdisc.label: MHPRESP
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: Not expect to receive these from the site. How this is populated in the sponsor's database would be up to the sponsor. If available, this would need to be an extension. The notion of pre-specified is part of the questionnaire

element.name: Prior Medical History Event

cdisc.label: MHSTRTPT*
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTMIG relative timing variable such as MHSTRF or MHSTRTPT. When populating MHSTRF, or MHSTRTPT if the value of the CDASH field MHPRIOR is "Y" a value from the CDISC CT (STENRF) may be used. When MHPRIOR refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTMIG variable MHSTRF should be populated. When MHPRIOR is compared to another time point, the SDTMIG variables MHSTRTPT and MHSTTPT should be used.

cdisc.label: MHSTRF*
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTMIG relative timing variable such as MHSTRF or MHSTRTPT. When populating MHSTRF, or MHSTRTPT if the value of the CDASH field MHPRIOR is "Y" a value from the CDISC CT (STENRF) may be used. When MHPRIOR refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTMIG variable MHSTRF should be populated. When MHPRIOR is compared to another time point, the SDTMIG variables MHSTRTPT and MHSTTPT should be used.

element.gap:
This can be determined from either the onsetDateTime and/or the abatementDateTime. If it were to be flagged on the record, it would need to be an extension on the extension that links to the study.
The sponsor may determine this, based on an anchor point in the protocol.

cdisc.label: MHENRF
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTMIG relative timing variable such as MHENRF or MHENRTPT. When populating MHENRF, if the value of the MHONGO is "Y" a value of "DURING", "AFTER" or "DURING/AFTER" may be used. When populating MHENRTPT, if the value of MHONGO is "Y", the value of "ONGOING" may be used. When MHONGO refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM>RFSTDTC to DM>RFENDTC) the SDTMIG variable MHENRF should be populated.

cdisc.label: MHENRTPT
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTMIG relative timing variable such as MHENRF or MHENRTPT. When populating MHENRF, if the value of the MHONGO is "Y" a value of "DURING", "AFTER" or "DURING/AFTER" may be used. When populating MHENRTPT, if the value of MHONGO is "Y", the value of "ONGOING" may be used. When MHONGO refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM>RFSTDTC to DM>RFENDTC) the SDTMIG variable MHENRF should be populated.

cdisc.label: MHSTDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MHSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.

cdisc.label: MHENDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MHENDTC in ISO 8601 format.

element.name: Medical History Event Location

cdisc.label: MHLOC*
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: AllergyIntolerances are generally not associated with body sites.

element.name: Medical History Event Laterality

cdisc.label: MHLAT*
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: There should be a standard extension defined that allows Condition, AdverseEvent, Observation and Specimen to point to a BodyStructure. Laterality is not relevant for allergies. Differentiation of laterality, directionality and other location qualifiers will require knowledge of the qualifier codes and code-by-code mapping

element.name: Medical History Directionality

cdisc.label: MHDIR*
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: There should be a standard extension defined that allows Condition, AdverseEvent, Observation and Specimen to point to a BodyStructure. Directionality is not relevant for allergies. Differentiation of laterality, directionality and other location qualifiers will require knowledge of the qualifier codes and code-by-code mapping

element.name: MH Event Location Portion or Totality

cdisc.label: MHPORTOT*
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: This would likely be an extension on Condition. It is not relevant for the other resources

element.name: MH Modified Reported Term

cdisc.label: MHMODIFY
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: In most cases, no MedDRA codes will be present in source data and all coding levels and displays will be added by the sponsor. However, FHIR allows multiple codings and therefore all of these codes *can* be conveyed in FHIR if the data source chooses to capture them. Standard code system URLs should be defined for each of the MedDRA levels. If MedDRA is considered a single code system, then the consumer will be responsible for distinguishing which codes represent which levels by looking up the received code.

element.name: MH Dictionary-Derived Term

cdisc.label: MHDECOD
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s). The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to code utilizing the Define-XML external code list attributes. Sponsors should include an Origin in the defined metadata document to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".

element.name: Study Identifier

cdisc.label: STUDYID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the MedicationStatement/Request/Dispense/Administration or Immunization is aware of its relevance to the Study.

element.name: Study Site Identifier

cdisc.label: DM.SITEID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the MedicationStatement/Request/Dispense/Administration or Immunization is aware of its relevance to the Study. ResearchStudy links to Patient. Observation links to Patient. If the patients are the same, that establishes the linkage. There's also an extension that allows direct linkage to a 'study' from any resource - if the source system has actually established such a linkage.

element.name: Subject Identifier for the Study

cdisc.label: DM.SUBJID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
Study subject is found by finding the StudySubject that corresponds to the same Patient and ResearchStudy as the focal resource.
No standard way to decide which subject identifier to use

element.name: Category for Medication

cdisc.label: CMCAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: In FHIR, an medication can be categorized in multiple ways and to the granularity desired. When converting from FHIR to CDASH, systems will need to look at the FHIR categories (and potentially other information) to determine how best to populate CMCAT and CMSCAT based on the study-designed categories (unless they've pre-arranged with the EHR to ensure it captures the same codes)

element.name: Subcategory for Medication

cdisc.label: CMSCAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: In FHIR, an medication can be categorized in multiple ways and to the granularity desired. When converting from FHIR to CDASH, systems will need to look at the FHIR categories (and potentially other information) to determine how best to populate CMCAT and CMSCAT based on the study-designed categories (unless they've pre-arranged with the EHR to ensure it captures the same codes)

element.name: Any Concomitant Medications Taken

cdisc.description: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM Annotated CRF is annotated to indicate that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.

element.gap:
This would be determined by dates within the protocol.
What constitutes a 'concomitant' drug is study-specific and would need to be evaluated on a study level. FHIR would not normally store that information. However an extension on ResearchSubject could be utilized or could be captured in a Questionnaire.

cdisc.label: CMSPID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s). May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.

cdisc.label: CMTRT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: Would not expect to receive from the site.

This information could be submitted in a SUPPCM dataset as the value of SUPPCM.QVAL where SUPPCM.QNAM= "MATC4CD" and SUPPCM.QLABEL="ATC Level 4 Code". Sponsors should include an Origin column in the SUPPQ dataset to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".

element.gap:
Encoding is performed by the sponsor and we would not expect to receive these from the site.
All coding levels are found in the same attribute as distinct codings. The granularity is distinguished by the code system or knowledge of the code

Sponsors should include an Origin column in the SUPPQ dataset to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".

element.gap: Encoding is performed by the sponsor and we would not expect to receive these from the site.

Encoding is performed by the sponsor and we would not expect to receive these from the site.

element.name: Study Identifier

cdisc.label: STUDYID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the Observation is aware of its relevance to the Study. ResearchStudy links to Patient. Observation links to Patient. If the patients are the same, that establishes the linkage. There's also an extension that allows direct linkage to a 'study' from any resource - if the source system has actually established such a linkage.

element.name: Study Site Identifier

cdisc.label: DM.SITEID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
Mapping is based on presumption that research subject will be tied to site-specific ResearchStudy, which will then be part of overall ResearchStudy.
The path using the extension will only exist if the system maintaining the Observation is aware of its relevance to the Study. ResearchStudy links to Patient. Observation links to Patient. If the patients are the same, that establishes the linkage. There's also an extension that allows direct linkage to a 'study' from any resource - if the source system has actually established such a linkage.

element.name: Subject Identifier for the Study

cdisc.label: DM.SUBJID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
Study subject is found by finding the StudySubject that corresponds to the same Patient and ResearchStudy as the Procedure.
No standard way to decide which subject identifier to use

element.name: Any Procedures Performed

cdisc.description: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM aCRF is annotated to indicate that this field is NOT SUBMITTED

element.gap: In FHIR, this would be determined by searching for Procedures with a given subject (possibly also filtered by research study) and excluding those that were entered in error. It might also be necessary to search for education, massage, cognitive therapy and various other data to determine all procedures.

element.name: Procedure Category

cdisc.label: PRCAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: FHIR doesn't have 2 distinct category levels. The option exists to have as many categorizations with whatever axes and granularities needed or desired. When mapping data to a particular study, it would be necessary to decide what category values best correspond to CAT vs. SCAT. A standard extension will be needed to convey multiple repetitions in R4. (Procedure.category does repeat in the draft of R5) The SNOMED binding is an example, which means that any codes can be used. Even if the binding were stronger, alternate codes would be possible on other repetitions.

element.name: Procedure Subcategory

cdisc.label: PRSCAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: FHIR doesn't have 2 distinct category levels. Instead, Procedure.category repeats. The option exists to have as many categorizations with whatever axes and granularities needed or desired. When mapping data to a particular study, it would be necessary to decide what category values best correspond to CAT vs. SCAT.

cdisc.label: PRSPID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.name: Reported Name of Procedure

cdisc.label: PRTRT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: The name as expressed by or displayed to the user goes in code.text. The name associated with the selected code goes in code.coding.display.

element.name: Standardized Procedure Name

cdisc.label: PRDECOD
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment:
Translation of the source-system-determined procedure code to the study-defined value set may need to be performed by the sponsor.
PRDECOD is the dictionary or the sponsor-defined standardized text description of PRTRT, or the modified topic variable (PRMODIFY), if applicable. This means it is the standardized term for the procedure.

element.name: Modified Procedure Name

cdisc.label: PRMODIFY*
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap:
Coding translations are conducted by the sponsor.
In FHIR, there's no need to modify the PRTERM. The text which was actually saw/typed (errors and all) is present and the various codes encoding it and the display names for those codes. If there was a need to capture a corrected text that was submitted to a post-coding process, that would be an extension

element.name: Procedure prespecified

cdisc.label: PRPRESP
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: This likely to be a Questionnaire question than something that would directly be captured in a record. This could possibly be an extension on the Procedure/MedicationAdministration/MedicationStatement.

element.name: Procedure Occurrence

cdisc.label: PROCCUR
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s). If the response was not asked or answered, populate the SDTMIG variable PRSTAT with "NOT DONE"

element.comment:
Coding translations are left to the sponsor.
Status of 'not-done', 'entered-in-error' would indicate that it didn't happen, 'active', 'in-progress', 'on-hold', 'completed' would indicate that it did. 'stopped' would indicate that it started, but was abnormally terminated - where that should go depends on the study's definition of 'occur'.

element.name: Procedure Reason for Occur Value

cdisc.label: SUPPPR.QVAL
cdisc.description: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM = "PRREASOC" and SUPPPR.QLABEL = "Reason for Occur Value". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variable I SDTM domains.

element.comment: Note that reasonReference would need to be turned into a code or string. Reason[x] indicates reason for doing the procedure; statusReason when status=not-done would be reason for non-occurrence

cdisc.label: PRREASND*
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.name: Prior Procedure

cdisc.label: PRSTRTPT
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTM relative timing variable such as PRSTRF or PRSTRTPT. When populating PRSTRF, or PRSTRTPT, if the value of the CDASH field PRPRIOR is "Y" a value from the CDISC CT (STENRF) may be used.

cdisc.label: PRSTRF*
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTM relative timing variable such as PRSTRF or PRSTRTPT. When populating PRSTRF, or PRSTRTPT, if the value of the CDASH field PRPRIOR is "Y" a value from the CDISC CT (STENRF) may be used.

element.comment: Typically, this extension won't exist, or won't be expressed relative to the subjects participation in the study. In such cases, the value for this element will need to be derived by the sponsor through comparision of procedure dates with study participation dates. If available, then the codes 'before-start' and 'before' map to 'true' and the rest map to false.

element.name: Procedure Start Date

cdisc.label: PRSTDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PRSTDTC in ISO 8601 format

element.comment: FHIR also allows performedString, but there is no way to map that to CDISC. The performedRange mapping is imprecise because it indicates imprecision around the performance rather than a specific start time.

element.name: Ongoing Procedure

cdisc.label: PRENRTPT
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTMIG relative timing variable such as PRENRF or PRENRTPT. When populating PRENRF, if the value of PRONGO is "Y", the value of "DURING", "AFTER" or "DURING/AFTER" may be used. When populating PRENRTPT, if the value of PRONGO is "Y", the value of "ONGOING" may be used. When PRONGO refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTM variable PRENRF should be populated. When PRONGO is used in conjunction with another time point, the SDTM variable PRENRRPT and PRENTPT should be used

cdisc.label: PRENRF*
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTMIG relative timing variable such as PRENRF or PRENRTPT. When populating PRENRF, if the value of PRONGO is "Y", the value of "DURING", "AFTER" or "DURING/AFTER" may be used. When populating PRENRTPT, if the value of PRONGO is "Y", the value of "ONGOING" may be used. When PRONGO refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTM variable PRENRF should be populated. When PRONGO is used in conjunction with another time point, the SDTM variable PRENRRPT and PRENTPT should be used

element.comment:
This supports the necessity of separating procedures and medication.
An example of ongoing procedure, "hemodialysis with frequency of three times a week". If the status is 'in-progress'/'active', then it's ongoing.

element.name: Procedure End Date

cdisc.label: PRENDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PRSTDTC in ISO 8601 format

element.comment: FHIR also allows performedString, but there is no way to map that to CDISC. The performedRange mapping is imprecise because it indicates imprecision around the performance rather than a specific end time.

element.name: Procedure Indication

cdisc.label: PRINDC
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: Note that reasonReference would need to be turned into a code or string.

cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PRSTDTC in ISO 8601 format

element.name: Related Medical History Event ID

cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For SDTM submission datasets, may be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in the eMedical History domain.

element.gap: If FHIR IDs are used for RELREC, then the sponsor should evaluate its use case as necessary prior to mapping.

element.name: Dose Description
element.gap: If FHIR IDs are used for RELREC, then the sponsor should evaluate its use case as necessary prior to mapping.

element.name: Procedure Dose Unit
