element.name: Procedure Route of Administration

cdisc.label: PRROUTE
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: This is a known gap. Procedure Route of Administration interval does NOT exist for 'Procedure'.

cdisc.label: PRLOC
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.name: Procedure Laterality

cdisc.label: PRLAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: This is frequently pre-coordinated into Procedure.bodySite. Multiple qualifiers are possible. Laterality will need to be recognized by code and/or system

element.name: Procedure Directionality

cdisc.label: PRDIR
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.comment: This is frequently pre-coordinated into Procedure.bodySite. Multiple qualifiers are possible. Directionality will need to be recognized by code and/or system

element.name: Procedure Portion or Totality

cdisc.label: PRPORTOT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: Typically this would be pre-coordinated into Procedure.code and would be captured in dosage instructions text for medications. If captured as a separate element, if would need to be an extension.

element.name: Procedure Fasting Status

cdisc.label: PRFAST*
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: This would be handled as an extension. Could propose as standard extension.

element.name: Procedure Intended Dose Regimen

cdisc.label: PRDOSRGM
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: An administration could be based on more than one thing (recommendation, plan, order) and in theory the intended dose would be different for each.

element.name: Procedure Adjusted

cdisc.description: When PRDOSADJ is collected, does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM Annotated CRF is annotated to indicate that this field is NOT SUBMITTED> When PRADJ is to collected, the sponsor may suit this variable as a SUPPQ.

element.gap: This would be handled as an extension. Would appear on Procedure/MedicationAdministration/MedicationStatement.basedOn. Might consider proposing it as a standard extension.

element.name: Reason for Procedure Adjustment

cdisc.label: PRADJ*
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: This would be handled as an extension. Would appear on Procedure/MedicationAdministration/MedicationStatement.basedOn. Might consider proposing it as a standard extension.

element.name: Completed Procedure

cdisc.label: SUPPPR.QVAL
cdisc.description: This does not map, directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM = "PRTRTCMP" and SUPPPR.QLABEL = "Treatment Completed".

element.gap: Not all potential mapping/FHIR resources/attributes will be addressed in this implementation guide. All data requires review and analysis to ensure the data is relevant and understood.

element.name: Procedure Interrupted

cdisc.description: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM a CRF is annotated to indicate that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.

element.comment: If something is currently interrupted, the status would either be on-hold or stopped. If there was a temporary interruption and the procedure has since resumed or completed, the only way to detect the interruption would be an extension or to review the history.

element.name: Reason Procedure Interrupted

cdisc.label: SUPPPR.QVAL
cdisc.description: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM = "PRITRPRS" and SUPPPR.QLABEL = "Reason intervention Interrupted". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variable.

element.comment: If the status is on-hold or stopped, statusReason would convey the reason. If there was a temporary interruption and the procedure has since resumed or completed, the only way to detect the interruption would be an extension or to review the history.

element.name: Procedure Interruption Duration

cdisc.label: SUPPPR.QVAL
cdisc.description: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM = "PRCINTD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL = "Intervention Duration". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variable.

element.gap: This would have to be an extension. Typically, you'd just look at history to see when something was suspended, then resumed.

element.name: Procedure Interruption Duration Units

cdisc.label: SUPPPR.QVAL
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM = "PRITRPD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL = "Interruption Duration". Concatenate the collected procedure interruption duration and the duration unit components and create PRITRPD using ISO 8601.

element.gap: This would have to be part of the previous extension. Typically, reviewing the history of the procedure will indicate if it was suspended and then resumed.

element.name: Procedure Lowest Level Term

cdisc.label: SUPPPR.QVAL
cdisc.description: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM = "PRLLT" and SUPPPR.QLABEL = "Lower Level Term". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variable.

element.comment:
Procedure Code is performed by the sponsor - not expected to receive this from the site or FHIR.
Procedure.code can contain many codings and at various levels of granularity. Granularity will be determined by reviewing the code system and/or having knowledge of the codes within the same code system (where one code system can express content at multiple granularities).

element.name: Procedure Lowest Level Term Code

cdisc.label: SUPPPR.QVAL
cdisc.description: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM = "PRLLTCD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL = "Lower Level Term Code". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variable.

element.comment:
Translation of Procedure.code to MeDRA will typically be performed by the sponsor and not provided in FHIR soure data.
Procedure.code can contain as many codings as you like at whatever granularity you like. You would distinguish what granularity it was by looking at the code system and/or having knowledge of the codes within the same code system (where one code system can express content at multiple granularities) Note: Not clear how many of these would be populated for a procedure.

element.name: Birth Date

cdisc.label: BRTHDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission data set, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable BRTHDTC in ISO 860 format.

element.comment:
There is potential where the birth date can not be collected due to country regulations. In those cases an estimated age may be entered.
Birth time is captured as a standard extension

cdisc.label: BRTHDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission data set, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable BRTHDTC in ISO 860 format.

cdisc.label: BRTHDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission data set, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable BRTHDTC in ISO 860 format.

cdisc.label: BRTHDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission data set, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable BRTHDTC in ISO 860 format.

cdisc.label: BRTHDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission data set, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable BRTHDTC in ISO 860 format.

element.name: Age

cdisc.label: AGE
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap:
There is potential where the birth date can not be collected due to country regulations.
Age can be captured either through additional filters, additional transformation, or occasionally looking for information in alternate loacations such as an Observation as a point-in-time assessment, but generally this is simply calculated from birthDate. Specifically, relevant clinical trial documentation will have expectations around units, other code systems and data consistency that may not be met by RWD and conversion and mapping may be necessary.

element.name: Age Units

cdisc.label: AGEU
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: Age can be captured as an Observation as a point-in-time assessment, but generally this is simply calculated from birthDate.

element.name: Demographics Collection Date

cdisc.label: DMDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission data set, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable BRTHDTC in ISO 860 format.

element.comment: This indicates when the Patient resource was last changed, but in practice different pieces of demographics are collected at different times. Review will be required of the history of the patient resource to determine when any particular fact was first asserted.

element.name: Sex

cdisc.label: SEX
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap:
Sex and gender are multi-faceted.concepts. Both FHIR and CDISC standards have a large degree of ambiguity in their definitions for their primary data elements describing a subject’s sex or gender (DM.SEX and Patient.gender). This ambiguity often exists in original source systems. Depending on the use case, the Various facets of sex and gender may be utilized or captured within clinical data.. - physiologic, social, chromosomal, etc. As such, it's not advisable to indicate a mapping where all the facets of sex and gender are ambiguous in both the source and study data standards. Study sponsors and regulators will need to establish policies and look into the quality and nature of the source data as well as the analysis that needs to be performed to determine appropriate mappings.
Extensions such as US core "birth sex" and FHIR core "gender identity" may give more semanticly consistent values, but may not be widely populated Some gender concepts such as physiologic and genetic characteristics may be captured as Observation values rather than as demographics elements on Patient

element.name: Ethnicity

cdisc.label: ETHNIC
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: There's a U.S. Core extension (https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/US-Core-R4/StructureDefinition-us-core-ethnicity.html) for this to capture ethnicity as required by U.S. legislation. It captures two distinct granularities as well as free text. Depending on the study, the higher or lower granularity might map to ETHNIC and the lower or free text could map to CETHNIC. Other countries use vastly different value sets or prohibit collection. If captured for clinical rather than administrative purposes, this would be an Observation

element.name: Collected Ethnicity

cdisc.label: SUPPDM.QVAL
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPDM dataset as the value of SUPPDM.QVAL where SUPPDM.QNAM = "CETHIC" and SUPPDM.QLABEL = "Collected Ethnicity" See SDTMIG v3.2 Section 5, DM Domain. Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variables in SDTM domains.

element.gap: There's a U.S. Core extension (https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/US-Core-R4/StructureDefinition-us-core-ethnicity.html) for this to capture ethnicity as required by U.S. legislation. It captures two distinct granularities as well as free text. Depending on the study, the higher or lower granularity might map to ETHNIC and the lower or free text could map to CETHNIC. Other countries use vastly different value sets or prohibit collection. If captured for clinical rather than administrative purposes, this would be an Observation

element.name: Race

cdisc.label: RACE
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap:
There's a U.S. Core extension (https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/US-Core-R4/StructureDefinition-us-core-race.html) for this to capture race as required by U.S. legislation. In theory, the OMBRace could map to RACE, 'detailed' could map to CRACE and 'text' could map to RACEOTH. However, how appropriate these mappings would be would depend on the study requirements.
Please note: the extension may or may not correspond to the sponsor's requirements and the extension can actually capture race information in 3 different ways, so further mapping would be needed. Other countries use vastly different value sets or prohibit collection. If captured for clinical rather than administrative purposes, this would be an Observation
